Reference [[Image:Edit-find.svg|left|86px|Technical documentation]] Ant reference pages. Ant users will be happy to learn that ControlTier has excellent [[Ant support]]. Ant is a first class citizen. Nearly the entire CTL Java API is exposed as Ant tasks and types. All context data provided by CTL is exposed to Ant build files as Ant properties files. [[Image:framework-4-ant.png]] The figure above highlights the Ant support in the CTL software framework. CTL adopts the "batteries included" metaphor incorporating a full Ant distribution (currently 1.7), ControlTier and third party task libraries (eg, ant-contrib, antxras) and a wide variety of supporting Java libraries. You can also add your own Ant library dependencies by copying them into the CTL's $ANT_HOME/lib directory. ==Ant commands== {{main|Ant command}} The [[type.xml]] module definition file is used to define new commands. To define a command using Ant tasks declare command-type="AntCommand". For the body of your command, define it inside a set of tags. Ant commands are, of course, defined using Ant tasks. An example is shown below:
==CTL's Controller Ant task== {{main| Controller Task Reference}} You are no doubt familiar with Ant tasks like Ant and AntCall to call another build file or another target in the same build file. These mechanisms allow you to break your builds into pieces so they are smaller, simpler and modular. CTL was designed with that kind of modularity in mind too and provides a similar mechanism, enabling one command to call another command. CTL provides an Ant task called [[Controller Task Reference|controller]] that gives you access to CTL's command dispatcher. Using this task you can invoke commands in local or remote modules. The [[Controller Task Reference|controller]] task includes a set of other tags letting you specify command line options and set any additional properties for the data context of the receiving command. {{Reference/navbox}} [[Category:Reference]]

<noinclude><categorytree mode=pages style="float:right; clear:right; margin-left:1ex; border:1px solid gray; padding:0.7ex; background-color:white;">Help</categorytree></noinclude>
The [[ControlTier server]] hosts a file share that supports the storage and distribution of files and packaged artifacts. The files may be the product of an internally developed software or orignate from a 3rd-party. The [[Graphical resource editor]] provides a graphical interface to browsing [[Package]]s stored in the file share.
The file share repository is based on Apache Jackrabbit an implementation of standard web technology, called WebDAV. All artifacts are accessible via HTTP and all storage operations can be done via a WebDAV client (eg, GET, PUT, DELETE, MKCOL).
[[Image:workbench-repository-cursory.png]]
Because the URL to the file share can be long and server specific, an abreviation can be used. See [[Dav:// prefix]] for examples.
See also the [[Davutil]] module for a set of commands that allow users to interact with the WebDAV store.
{{Manual/navbox}}
[[Category:Help]]

[[Image:Crystal_Clear_app_tutorials.png|right|75]] Modules Welcome to the Module Development Guide. This section of the manual provides information on how to declare commands executable by the CTL command dispatcher. The command dispatcher supports a number of different command types. Some command types are useful to encapsulate script code so command dispatcher can execute it. Other command types are used to structure workflows. You can also define parameters in your commands giving your users access to specify parameters. Commands are developed in a type with either [[ProjectBuilder]] or the [[Graphical type editor]]. See the [[Core Type Guide]] for existing types. ; [[First type module]] : How to create defined commands in a ControlTier type using XML and ProjectBuilder. Contains screencasts. '''Defining Commands:''' ; [[Shell command]] : How to wrap a shell command using the "Command" handler type. This command type is useful if you want to invoke an external script, or to define a shell script in line. ; [[Ant command]] : How to define a command using the "AntCommand" handler type. This command type is useful if you want to use Ant tasks to carry out your procedure. ; [[BSF command]] : How to define a command using the "BsfCommand" handler type. This command type is useful if you want to use one of the Bean Scripting Framework languages to implement your procedure. ; [[:Category:Workflow Commands|Workflow command]] : How to define a command using the "WorkflowCommand" handler type. This command type is useful if you want to call a sequence of commands defined in your type. ; [[:Category:Dispatch commands|Dispatch command type]] : Shows how to dispatch a command across a set of objects. ; [[:Category:Command Options|Command options]] : How to define parameters for your commands. Parameters can be [[Boolean option|boolean]], or take a [[String option|string]] argument. ; [[:Category:Object-orientation|Object-orientation]] : Describes how to [[Override an inherited command|override inherited commands]], call [[Calling a supertype command|supertype commands]] and use the [[Template method pattern]]. Types [[File:Icon-NodeObject.png]] The Node Type represents a computer host registered in a ControlTier [[Project|project]]. The command dispatcher can execute commands to any registered Node. Nodes are also used to when modeling [[Service|Services]] and [[Package|Packages]] deployments. ==Reference== * [http://controltier.sourceforge.net/docs/latest/core/reference/user/Node/index.html Node Reference] [[File:Core-type-model.png|thumb|Core type model]] ==Definition== ===Metadata=== Each Node is described with these properties: {{Project.xml/tags/node}} Nodes can be defined in a project resource model in one of several ways: * [[Graphical resource editor]]: In Workbench * Via modelutil command: [[modelutil]]'s node-set command * Project XML: [[project.xml]] * Client setup: Using [[ctl-project]] Each of these methods is described in their own section below. ===Graphical resource editor=== {{Main|Graphical resource editor#Node_Manager}} Nodes can be defined using the [[Graphical resource editor]]. From the home page, go to the "Node Manager". Once there press the "Create new object" button. Pressing that button will direct the browser to the node creation form. [[Image:Node-create-form.png]] ===Via modelutil command=== Nodes can be registered via the [[modelutil]] [http://controltier.sourceforge.net/docs/snapshot/core/reference/user/modelutil/commands/node-set.html node-set] command: ctl -p demo -m modelutil -c node-set --\ -name centos2 -hostname centos2 -osfamily unix -osname Linux -osarch i386 -ctluser alexh -tags mytag -description 'second centos host' This example shows how a host named "centos2" is registered as a node in the project named "demo". ===Project XML=== {{Main| Bulk Node registration}} A node can be defined in XML using the [[project.xml]] format. Here is an example. You can load this XML file using the [[ProjectBuilder]] load-resources command like so: ctl -p demo -m ProjectBuilder -c load-resources -- -filename node.xml This XML definition is loaded to the "demo" project maintained on the server. ===Client setup=== {{Main|Creating a project#ControlTier client setup}} On nodes where the ControlTier client is installed, hosts are registered as nodes during project setup with ctl-project. During project setup, the [[CTL-PROJECT Command Reference|ctl-project]] command registers the node in the specified project name. ===Querying=== You can lookup registered nodes from the command line. The [[ctl-exec]] command can list all registered nodes. Run it without arguments: ctl-exec -p project You can also use the [[ProjectBuilder]] find-resources command to query with criteria: ctl -p project -m ProjectBuilder -c find-resources -- -type Node -name 'dev.*' The [[modelutil]] find command can also query the resource model for matching Nodes. [[Image:icon-large-NodeObject.png]] For a graphical alternative, you can use the [[Graphical resource editor]] and view the nodes there. Go to the [[Graphical_resource_editor#Node_list|Node list]]. You will see it list all nodes. {{Guide/navbox}} {{Manual/navbox|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:Types]]

Types [[ProjectBuilder]] provides a set of utilities to define types, commands, build module libraries, load resource data, even generate a Forrest documentation site. For type and module development, ProjectBuilder supports a typical edit, build, test methodology familiar to most developers wherein, a set of source files maintained in a source code repository are developed using familiar text editing tools, and ProjectBuilder builds and deploys them, so that the results can be distributed and used. ==Reference== * [http://controltier.sourceforge.net/docs/latest/core/reference/user/ProjectBuilder/index.html ProjectBuilder Reference] == To create types== ProjectBuilder provides two primary commands to create and build new modules: * create-type — Creates a set of source files containing a boilerplate type definition * build-type — Processes the type's source files and generates a Jar file that can be loaded into Workbench or distributed to CTL hosts. If you are a new user (or new to ProjectBuilder) review the following pages: ; [[Use ProjectBuilder]] : Introduces ProjectBuilder and how to configure it to manage a set of source files to maintain a project. ''See a [http://open.controltier.com/media/tutorial-Use-ProjectBuilder.swf screencast]'' ; [[First CTL module|First custom type]] : Describes how to use the create-type command to create a new module source tree. ''See a [http://open.controltier.com/media/tutorial-Create-CTL-Module-1.swf screencast (part 1)], [http://open.controltier.com/media/tutorial-Create-CTL-Module-2.swf (part 2)]'' You can of course use the graphical [[Graphical type editor]] to define your types and commands and then later export them as source files. See [[Converting Workbench modules for use with ProjectBuilder]]. ProjectBuilder is a utility module based on [[Builder]] containing commands used to create and manage project artifacts such as types, resources and jobs. You can use ProjectBuilder commands on any host as it connects to the server over the network. ==Definition== ===Project XML=== A ProjectBuilder can be registered in XML using the [[project.xml]] format. See [[Use ProjectBuilder]] for a step by step example of defining a ProjectBuilder. ===1.2 Querying=== Use the [[ProjectBuilder]] find-resources command to list all "ProjectBuilder" instances: 
 $ ctl -p demo -m ProjectBuilder -c find-resources -- -type ProjectBuilder
 |
 |--(ProjectBuilder) core
[[Image:icon-large-BuilderObject.png]] For a graphical alternative, you can use the [[Graphical resource editor]] and view the builders there. Go to the [[Graphical_resource_editor#Builder_list|Builder list]]. You will see it list all builders. [[Category:Projects]] [[Category:Types]]

This document is a guide to the Core Types included with ControlTier. Core Types declare commands executable via the [[Command dispatcher]]. The default ControlTier distribution contains other subtypes which are not mentioned here. ''If you are new to ControlTier, the [[How to use ControlTier]] page describes common methodologies about using the types.''
The category tree to the right is included in all the core type pages and will assist navigating the core types or type guides. __NOTOC__ ==Organization== [[Image:core-type-model.png|thumb|Core Type UML Diagram]]
For the sake of discussion the core types are organized into three rough layers: * Base: These types are low level and basic abstractions that describe generic resources * Utility: These types offer collections of utilities arranged by subject and are useful for those defining script-based solutions. * Deployment: These types represent design patterns for managing multi-tier application deployments.
The UML diagram to the right describes the core types showing the inheritance hierarchy and also their composition relationships.
Depending on your use case, you will be interested in some of the core types but not necessarily all of them. Each layer described above is covered in its own guide. All the guides are cross linked for the sake of navigation.
[[Image:core-type-model-example.png|thumb|Core Type Object Example]]

Webapps [[Workbench]] is a ControlTier webapp running on the [[ControlTier server]]. Workbench is a multi-purpose server and end-user application that combines several functions: ; [[Graphical resource editor]] : The Graphical resource editor lets you create inventories of physical and application details. [[Image:Workbench-cmrepository-cursory.png]] ; [[Graphical type editor]] : The [[Graphical type editor]] is built on the concept of integrating configuration data and automation code. If the idea of describing application configuration appeals to you, then one of the greatest benefits that results is data-driven automation. The configuration data stored in the Workbench repository can be used to provide key operational details to your scripts (such as environment specific values like ports, passwords, keys, application settings), and even relationship info (like what database instance does a given application server use, or to which hosts are my web servers deployed). Workbench provides a web-based graphical interface to defining new resource types, as well as, automation types that lets you connect your scripts to the repository data. [[Image:Workbench-designer-cursory.png]] ; [[File share]] : The [[File share]] can be used as a storage system where you can maintain packaged artifacts or any other file-based asset needed by your operation. [[Image:Workbench-repository-cursory.png]] {{Installation/navbox}} [[Category:Webapps]]

Workflow commands represent a sequence of commands. This category is part of the [[Module Development Guide]].
Workflows represent an automated process that spans a series of steps. Each step in the workflow is carried out by a command defined in a type.
Workflow execution can be graphically displayed inside [[Workbench]] using the "process flow view". The process flow view shows the series of commands that will be executed for a given resource model. This same view can also be seen in the Jobcenter when watching a process execute.
[[File:DukesBank-Updater-Update-pview.png|Workbench process flow]]
[[File:Jc-process-view-mode.png|Jobcenter process flow]]

==XML document types== ControlTier uses several XML file types to describe various aspects of a [[Project]]. ; [[Type.xml]] : defines a set of related [[Types]] and is used to develop processes and [[Type modeling]]. :* Load this file with [[ProjectBuilder]] → {{corecmd|ProjectBuilder|build-type}} :* Exported from [[Workbench]]. ; [[Project.xml]] : defines a set of Resources, and is used to develop the [[Resource Model]]. :* Load this file with [[ProjectBuilder]] → {{corecmd|ProjectBuilder|load-objects}} :* Exported from [[Workbench]]. ; [[Acls.xml]] : defines Access Control for use within [[CTL]] and [[Jobcenter]]. :* Stored within the [[CTL_BASE]]/etc directory. ; [[Job.xml]] : defines a set of Job definitions for use with [[Jobcenter]]. :* Imported/Exported from [[Jobcenter]]. :* Imported/Exported with [[ProjectBuilder]] → {{corecmd|ProjectBuilder|load-jobs}}, and {{corecmd|ProjectBuilder|find-jobs}}.
